etymologies: late 18th century (in an earlier sense). From German Schneider tailor (already in Middle High German as snīdǣre), (in extended use, in skat and schafkopf) the fact of either side (solo player or defenders) taking 30 or fewer points in tricks from schneiden to cut + -er

definitions: In skat and schafkopf: a result such that the declaring player or team wins with ninety-one or more points, or the opposing team wins with ninety or more points out of a total of one hundred and twenty points. In modern German skat: a result such that either side wins with ninety or more points. Also in "out of schneider": no longer at risk of losing in such a way as a result of scoring at least thirty or thirty-one points. Also as interjection: a declaration by a player that he or she intends to win with such a result.
In gin rummy: a result where a player loses the game having scored no points.

In skat and schafkopf: (of the opposing team) defeated with a score of less than thirty; (of the declaring player or team) defeated with a score of less than thirty-one. In modern German skat: (of either side) defeated with a score of less than thirty-one.
In skat and schafkopf: to defeat (an opponent or opponent's hand) by achieving schneider.

notes.text: The result is schneider if the declaring player or team score ninety-one or more points, or the opposing team score ninety or more points out of a possible one hundred and twenty.

definitions: In gin rummy: to defeat (an opponent) by causing him or her to lose the game having scored no points.
